hints.content: Start by understanding the problem statement clearly. You need to determine if you can reach the last index of the array based on the jump lengths specified in the array.
Consider what it means to jump from one index to another. Each value in the array indicates the maximum number of steps you can jump forward from that index.
Think about edge cases. For example, what happens if the array has only one element? Can you reach the last index then?
Try to visualize the jumps. For instance, if you're at index 0 with a value of 2, you can jump to index 1 or index 2. What are the implications of those choices?
A useful approach is to keep track of the furthest index you can reach as you iterate through the array. Start with the first index and see how far you can go.

As you iterate through the array, update your maximum reachable index based on the current index and its jump length. If at any point your current index exceeds the maximum reachable index, you cannot proceed.
Consider using a loop to iterate through the array. For each index, check if you can reach it based on the maximum reachable index you've calculated so far.
Remember to check if the maximum reachable index is at least the last index of the array after your iteration. If it is, return true; otherwise, return false.
Think about the time complexity of your solution. Can you achieve it in linear time, O(n)? This is important given the constraints of the problem.
To finalize your approach, implement the logic where you maintain a variable for the maximum reachable index and iterate through the array to check if you can reach the last index.

questionNotes: You start at index 0 and need to reach the last index.
Return true if you can reach the last index, false otherwise.
